title: 115_hr5270
content: The "Electricity Reliability and Fuel Security Act" includes a Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under SEC. 45T. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under SEC. 45T allows taxpayers who own or lease a coal-powered electric generation unit to claim a credit equal to 30% of qualified expenses or $13 multiplied by the unit's capacity rating. Qualified expenses are defined as amounts paid for the operation of the unit. A coal-powered electric generation unit must use coal for at least 75% of the electricity produced to qualify for the credit. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under SEC. 45T allows taxpayers to claim a credit for qualified expenses related to the operation of a coal-powered electric generation unit. Qualified expenses do not include amounts paid for coal. Public entities can transfer the credit to eligible project partners. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under SEC. 45T allows eligible project partners to elect to be treated as the taxpayer for the credit instead of the qualified public entity. The term 'qualified public entity' refers to government entities or cooperative electric organizations. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under SEC. 45T allows eligible project partners, including government entities, cooperative electric organizations, and not-for-profit electric utilities that received a loan under the Rural Electrification Act of 1936, to be treated as the taxpayer for the credit. Eligible project partners are individuals responsible for operating, maintaining, or repairing coal-powered electric generation units. The term 'eligible project partner' refers to individuals responsible for operating, maintaining, or repairing a coal-powered electric generation unit, participating in coal provision, providing financing, or leasing the unit. Special rules apply to partnerships for tax credits. The term 'eligible project partner' includes partners of a partnership for tax credit purposes. Credits are taken into account in the first taxable year of the eligible project partner. The eligible project partner can take the credit in the first taxable year after the qualified public entity's taxable year. Any benefit from the election under this subsection is not considered private business use. If a credit is allowed for a coal-powered electric generation unit, the property's basis is reduced by the amount of the credit. The basis of a coal-powered electric generation unit is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed. This section applies to taxable years from 2018 to 2022. The credit for a coal-powered electric generation unit is reduced by the amount allowed, applicable for taxable years 2018-2022. A new clause is added to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The credit for a coal-powered electric generation unit is reduced for taxable years 2018-2022. A new clause is added to the tax code.
